quoteFirst: â€œIt remained to check Billingford's story as far as possible, and you know how the runnel helped us in that. What the facts of the case proved beyond any reasonable doubt was that at
quoteLast: Billingford was about three-quarters of a mile from Neptune's Seat. With the sound of the sea in his ears, it's most unlikely that he could hear a pistol-shot at that distance.
title: Mystery at Lynden Sands
author: Connington, J. J., 1880-1947

quoteFirst: After that, if he'd returned the way he came, he could have emerged from the runnel at the same point, only on this bank of the channel, and left his single track up to Neptune's Seat, just as we found it. But that won't fit in with the shot fired at
quoteLast: , obviously. If he'd done this, then his last footmark on the far side would have been made when the runnel was full, and his first footmark on this side would have been made later, when the runnel had shrunk a bit; and the two wouldn't have fitted the banks neatly as we found to-night that they did.
title: Mystery at Lynden Sands
author: Connington, J. J., 1880-1947
